speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) concluded a two-day meeting earlier today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you already know from our statement, the Committee decided, starting next month, to modestly reduce the pace at which it is increasing the size of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee also clarified its guidance on interest rates, emphasizing that the current near-zero range for the federal funds rate target likely will remain appropriate well past the time that the unemployment rate declines below 6½ percent, especially if projected inflation continues to run below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Today’s policy actions reflect the Committee’s assessment that the economy is continuing to make progress, but that it also has much farther to travel before conditions can be judged normal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Notably, despite significant fiscal headwinds, the economy has been expanding at a moderate pace, and we expect that growth will pick up somewhat in coming quarters, helped by highly accommodative monetary policy and waning fiscal drag.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The job market has continued to improve, with the unemployment rate having declined further.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At the same time, the recovery clearly remains far from complete, with unemployment still elevated and with both underemployment and long-term unemployment still major concerns.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have also seen ongoing declines in labor force participation, which likely reflect not only longer-term influences, such as the aging of the population, but also discouragement on the part of potential workers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Inflation has been running below the Committee’s longer-run objective of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee recognizes that inflation persistently below its objective could pose risks to economic performance and is monitoring inflation developments carefully for evidence that inflation will move back toward its objective over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: This outlook is broadly consistent with individual economic projections submitted in conjunction with this meeting by the 17 FOMC participants—5 Board members and 12 Reserve Bank presidents.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As always, each participant’s projections are conditioned on his or her own view of appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: FOMC participants generally expect economic growth to pick up somewhat over the next few years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Their projections for increases in gross domestic product have a central tendency of 2.2 to 2.3 percent for 2013, rising to between 2.8 and 3.2 percent for next year, with similar growth estimates for 2015 and 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Participants see the unemployment rate, which was 7 percent in November, as continuing to decline.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The central tendency of the projections has the unemployment rate falling to between 6.3 and 6.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 2014 and then to between 5.3 and 5.8 percent by the final quarter of 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Meanwhile, FOMC participants continue to see inflation running below our 2 percent objective for a time but moving gradually back toward 2 percent as the economy expands.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The central tendency of their inflation projections for 2013 is 0.9 to 1.0 percent, rising to 1.4 to 1.6 percent for next year and to between 1.7 and 2.0 percent in 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me now return to our decision to reduce the pace of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: When we began the asset purchase program in September 2012, we said that we would continue purchases until the outlook for the labor market had improved substantially in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Since then, we have seen meaningful cumulative progress in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, since we began the current purchase program, the economy has added about 2.9 million jobs and the unemployment rate has fallen by more than a percentage point, to 7 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For comparison, when we started the program, many forecasters saw the unemployment rate remaining near 8 percent throughout 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Recent economic indicators have increased our confidence that the job market gains will continue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, nonfarm payrolls have recently been increasing at a pace of about 200,000 jobs per month, and the unemployment rate has fallen by 0.6 percentage point since June.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: With fiscal restraint likely diminishing and with signs that household spending is picking up, we expect economic growth to be strong enough to support further job gains.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Further, FOMC participants now see the risks around their forecasts of growth and unemployment as having become more nearly balanced, rather than tilted in an unfavorable direction as they were at the inception of the asset purchase program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you know, we have been purchasing $85 billion per month in longer-term Treasury and agency mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Starting in January, we will be purchasing $75 billion of securities a month, reducing purchases of Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities by $5 billion each.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It is important to note though that, even after this reduction, we will be still expanding our holdings of longer-term securities at a rapid pace.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We will also continue to roll over maturing Treasury securities and reinvest principal payments from the Federal Reserve’s holdings of agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities into agency mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our sizable and still-increasing holdings will continue to put downward pressure on longer-term interest rates, support mortgage markets, and make financial conditions more accommodative, which in turn should promote further progress in the labor market and help move inflation back toward the Committee’s objective of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our modest reduction in the pace of asset purchases reflects the Committee’s belief that progress toward its economic objectives will be sustained.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If the incoming data broadly support the Committee’s outlook for employment and inflation, we will likely reduce the pace of securities purchases in further measured steps at future meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Of course, continued progress is by no means certain.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Consequently, future adjustments to the pace of asset purchases will be deliberate and dependent on incoming information.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Asset purchases remain a useful tool that we are prepared to deploy as needed to meet our objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: With unemployment still well above its longer-run normal rate, which Committee participants currently estimate to be between 5.2 and 5.8 percent, and with inflation continuing to run below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-term objective, highly accommodative monetary policy remains appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To emphasize its commitment to provide a high level of monetary accommodation for as long as needed, the FOMC today also enhanced its forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For the past year, the Committee has said that the current low target range for the federal funds rate would be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remained above 6½ percent, inflation was projected to be no more than half a percentage point above our 2 percent longer-run goal, and longer-term inflation expectations remained well anchored.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have emphasized that these numbers are thresholds, not triggers, meaning that crossing a threshold would not lead automatically to an increase in the federal funds rate but would indicate only that it was appropriate for the Committee to consider whether the broader economic outlook justified such an increase.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: With many FOMC participants now projecting that the 6½ percent unemployment threshold will be reached by the end of 2014, the Committee decided to provide additional information about how it expects its policies to evolve after the threshold is crossed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Based on its assessment of current conditions and the outlook, which is informed by a range of indicators, including measures of labor market conditions, financial conditions, and inflation pressures, the Committee now anticipates it will likely be appropriate to maintain the current federal funds rate target well past the time that the unemployment rate declines to below 6½ percent, especially if projected inflation continues to run below its 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In part, this expectation reflects our assessment, based on a comprehensive set of indicators, that there will still be a substantial amount of slack in the labor market when the unemployment rate falls to 6½ percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: This continuing job market slack imposes heavy costs on the unemployed and the underemployed and their families and reduces our nation’s productive capacity, warranting our ongoing highly accommodative policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, as the last phrase of the enhanced guidance underscores, the prospects for inflation provide another reason to keep policy accommodative.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee is determined to avoid inflation that is too low as well as inflation that is too high, and it anticipates keeping rates low at least until it sees inflation clearly moving back toward its 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our forward guidance is reflected in Committee participants’ latest projections for the path of the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Although the central tendency of the projected unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of next year encompasses 6½ percent, 15 of 17 FOMC participants do not expect a rate increase before 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most see our target for the federal funds rate as rising only modestly in 2015, while 3 do not see an increase until 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For all participants, the median projection for the federal funds rate is 75 basis points at the end of 2015 and 1.75 percent at the end of 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In summary, reflecting cumulative progress and an improved outlook for the job market, the Committee decided today to modestly reduce the monthly pace at which it is adding to the longer-term securities on its balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If incoming information supports the Committee’s expectation of further progress toward its objectives, the Committee is likely to reduce the pace of monthly purchases in further measured steps in future meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, the process will be deliberate and data-dependent; asset purchases are not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The FOMC also provided additional guidance on future short-term interest rates, stating that it expects to maintain the federal funds target in its current near-zero range well past the time that the unemployment rate falls below 6½ percent, especially if projected inflation continues to run below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Reserve’s enhanced guidance about its policy intentions and its substantial and still-increasing holdings of longer-term securities will ensure that monetary policy remains highly accommodative, consistent with the pursuit of its mandated objectives of maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’ll be glad to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, as I said, the steps that we take will be data-dependent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If we’re making progress in terms of inflation and continued job gains—and I imagine we’ll continue to do, probably at each meeting, a measured reduction—that would take us to late in the year, certainly not by the middle of the year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If the economy slows for some reason or we are disappointed in the outcomes, we could skip a meeting or two.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the other side, if things really pick up, then of course we could go a bit faster, but my expectation is for similar moderate steps going forward throughout most of 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the first issue of $10 billion, again, we say we are going to take further modest steps subsequently, so that would be the general range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But again, I want to emphasize that we are going to be data-dependent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We could stop purchases if the economy disappoints.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We could pick them up somewhat if the economy is stronger.1 In terms of MBS versus Treasuries, we discussed that issue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think that the general sense of the Committee was that equal reductions, or approximately equal reductions, was the simpler way to do this.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It obviously doesn’t make a great deal of difference in the end to how much we hold.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that was going to be our strategy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the issue of another number, the unemployment rate—let’s talk first about the labor market condition.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The unemployment rate is a good indicator of the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s probably the best single indicator that we have.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so we were comfortable setting a 6.5 percent unemployment rate as the point at which we would begin to look at a more broad set of labor market indicators.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, precisely because we don’t want to look just at the unemployment rate, we want to—once we get to 6½—we want to look at hiring, quits, vacancies, participation, long-term unemployment, et cetera, wages.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We couldn’t put it in terms of another unemployment rate level, specifically.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I expect there will be some time past the 6½ percent before all of the other variables that we’ll be looking at will line up in a way that will give us confidence that the labor market is strong enough to withstand the beginning of increases in rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: 1 The Chairman meant to say: “We could stop the reductions in the pace of purchases if the economy disappoints.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We could reduce the pace of purchases somewhat more quickly if the economy is stronger.” The SEP, the Survey of Economic Projections, which were distributed, obviously that’s individual assessments and not the Committee’s collective view.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But nevertheless, it gives you some sense of current expectations about the length of time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The SEP shows that the 6.5 percent is expected by a large number of people to be reached about at the end of next year, end of 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And then the first rate increases, according to the so-called dots chart, take place near the end of 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s the order of the magnitude, I think, that people are currently expecting, but again I emphasize that it will depend on our being persuaded that—over, across a broad range of indicators—the labor market is sufficiently strong that we could begin to withdraw accommodation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Yes, it will.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I have always consulted closely with Janet, even well before she was named by the President, and I consulted closely with her on these decisions as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And she fully supports what we did today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, again, these are individual estimates, there are big standard errors implicitly around them and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do think that inflation will gradually move back to 2 percent, and we allow for the possibility, as you know, in our guidance that it could go as high as 2½ percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Even though inflation has been quite low in 2013, let me give you the case for why inflation might rise.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: First, there are some special factors, such as health-care costs and some other things, that have been unusually low and might be reversed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Secondly, if you look at the fundamentals for inflation, including inflation expectations, whether measured by financial markets or surveys; if you look at growth, which we now anticipate will be picking up both in the U.S. and internationally; if you look at wages, which have been growing at 2 percent and a little bit higher according to many indicators—all of these things suggest that inflation will gradually pick up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But what I tried to emphasize in my opening remarks, and which is clear in our statement, is that we take this very seriously.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s not easy to—inflation cannot be picked up and moved where you want it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It takes—it requires, obviously, some luck and some good policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we are very committed to making sure that inflation does not stay too low, and we are continuing to monitor that very carefully and to take whatever actions necessary to achieve that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, even under optimal control, it would take a while for inflation—inflation is quite—can be quite inertial.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It can take quite a time to move.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the responsiveness of inflation to increasing economic activity is quite low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So—and particularly given an environment where we have falling oil prices and other factors that are contributing downward forces on inflation, it’s difficult to get inflation to move quickly to target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we are, again, committed to doing what’s necessary to get inflation back to target over the next couple of years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, everything depends on what benchmark you compare it to, as you know.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I said last year that monetary policy was not a panacea.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It couldn’t solve all our problems.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, in particular, it can’t do anything about a slowing in potential growth, which appears to have happened, at least to some extent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It can’t do much or anything about fiscal policy, which is working in quite the opposite direction.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, given those things, I think the outcomes we’ve had are perhaps not as bad as you would—might think.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, as I’ve mentioned many times, the Congressional Budget Office assessed the fiscal drag in 2013 as being about 1½ percentage points of growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re looking like we’re going to get in the low 2s actual growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Add those numbers together, it’s kind of a counterfactual.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It says that monetary policy appears to have succeeded in offsetting a good bit of that fiscal drag, which we were not at all sure that we could accomplish.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we’re certainly not giving up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We intend to maintain a highly accommodative policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Nothing that we did today was intended to reduce accommodation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re still going to be buying assets at a high rate and increasing and holding—increasing our balance sheet and holding on to those assets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In our guidance today— we strengthened our guidance to make clear that we expect to keep rates low well beyond the point that unemployment hits 6½ percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, certainly, it’s a very—it was a very important decision, and we debated it quite extensively.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that criterion, of course, was a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And if you look at the cumulative improvement—and I mentioned some figures in my opening remarks—or if you look at recent numbers, either on employment, unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And also in terms of growth, we’re seeing encouraging numbers in terms of household spending, for example, auto purchases, fiscal drag is reduced, stronger numbers internationally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, I don’t want to overstate the case.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you look at our projections, you’ll see we only assume or project a small pickup in growth going into next year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But there was a pretty widespread view that there was a reasonable expectation, first, that the recent gains in the labor market would continue—and, remember, we’re just beginning this process now, so by the time we complete this process, I think it’s very likely that we’ll easily pass the hurdle of a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, it is true that while we have passed the—or, made significant progress on the labor market and growth hurdles, there is still this question about inflation, which is a bit of a concern—more than a bit of concern, as we indicated in our statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our outlook is still for inflation to go back to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I gave you some reasons why I think that will happen.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we take that very seriously, and if inflation does not show signs of returning to target, we will take appropriate action.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, in terms of the legal authorities that the Federal Reserve has, we don’t have some of the— REBECCA JARVIS.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If you could ask for it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If we could ask for it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, we’re getting now to a fanciful discussion, I think.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think our basic tools are asset purchases, and we are allowed only to buy Treasuries and agency securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are not allowed to buy corporates or other things, the way many central banks are.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have—with interest rates near zero, we can manage our forward guidance, and I think that has been helpful, that’s been effective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We probably could do more with that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But there are limits to that as well because, beyond a certain point, markets may not accept—you know, may not view the long-distance, way-ahead guidance as being credible.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We can change the interest rate we pay on reserves, which is something we’ve talked about.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The other kind of thing that—the only other thing I can think of that amounts to a direct infusion into the economy, if you will, is action similar to the British Funding for Lending program, where they provided cheap funding to banks if the banks could show that they had increased their lending to households or small businesses.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We could, in principle, do something like that, and we’ve looked at that because we do have a discount window where we lend to banks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, somewhat differently from what was going on in the U.K. and in Europe, here, our banks are flush with liquidity, they have plenty of cash on hand—they own lots of reserves, of course.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so our sense was that there just wouldn’t be any take up on that program, at least under current conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do not have the authority to lend directly to small businesses or other types of institutions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And in any case, I don’t think right now that tight credit, in most areas, is the major problem.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think what we have, in many cases, is that firms are either not looking for credit or their balance sheets are not strong enough that they pass creditworthy screenings at the bank.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we do have a range of things that we can do, but we are already being, I think, pretty aggressive.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Under some circumstances, yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The answer to the first question is “no.” The answer to the second question is “I’ll be interested to see.” I hope I live long enough to read the textbooks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The—what we’ve showed—there’ve been two big changes, at least—more than two, but two that I would cite at the Fed in the last few years, of course, the result, in many ways, of the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The first is that the Federal Reserve has rediscovered its roots, in the sense that the Fed was created to stabilize the financial system in times of panic.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we did that, and we used tools that were analogous in spirit to what central banks have done for many hundreds of years, but, of course, adapted to a modern financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The other thing that was unique about—maybe not completely unique, but largely unique about this period was that we were trying to help the economy recover from a deep recession at a time when interest rates were almost, or essentially, zero.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that required us to use other methods—most prominently, forward guidance and asset purchases, neither of which is entirely new.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, clearly, this is—unless you put aside the Depression, where monetary policy was, on the whole, pretty passive—this is the first—one of the first examples, at least, of aggressive monetary policy taking place in a near-zero interest rate environment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now we’re seeing, of course, Japan and the U.K. and other countries also taking similar types of approaches.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think that will be an issue—an area that monetary historians will be interested in exploring, as well as monetary theorists and empirical studies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, as I said before, asset purchases are a supplementary tool.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our main tool is interest rate policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The reason that asset purchases are a supplementary tool is because it’s a much less familiar tool.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have less ability to calibrate how big the effects are, for example.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And it’s also true that, as the balance sheet of the Federal Reserve gets large, managing that balance sheet, exiting from that balance sheet become more difficult.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And there are concerns about effects on asset prices, although, I would have to say that’s another thing that future monetary economists will want to be looking at very carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, our view was—in September 2012—was that we had interest rates already low, and they were expected to stay low for a good long time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The economy, though, was faltering.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We needed an additional boost.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so we brought in the asset purchase program again.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We put in a specific objective, which is substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our sense was once that intermediate objective was attained—that is, when the economy had grown and was moving forward—that, at that point, we could begin to wind down the secondary tool, the supplementary tool, and achieve essentially the same amount of accommodation using interest rates and forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, I do want to reiterate that this is not intended to be a tightening.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We don’t think that there’s an inflation problem or anything like that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the one hand, asset purchases are still going to be continuing, we’re still going to be building our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The total amount of assets that we acquire are probably more than was—certainly more than what was expected in September 2012 or in June 2013.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’ll have a very substantial balance sheet, which we’ll continue to hold.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And now we’ve also clarified our guidance that we will be keeping rates low well past unemployment of 6.5 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’re trying here to get a high level of accommodation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It is true that the purchases are—we view as supplementary to the interest rate policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, the action today is intended to keep the level of accommodation more or less the same overall and enough to push the economy forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think we want to make an assessment now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I wouldn’t expect any changes in the very near term.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We want to see how much accommodation we have and whether it’s sufficient, whether the economy is continuing to grow, and inflation is moving back toward target, as we anticipate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But there are things we can do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We can strengthen the guidance in various ways.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And while the view of the Committee was that the best way forward today was in this more qualitative approach, which incorporates elements both of the unemployment threshold and the inflation floor, that further strengthening would be possible, and it’s something that has certainly not been ruled out.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, of course, asset purchases are still there to be used.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do have tools to manage a large balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve made a lot of progress on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So while, again, while we think that we can provide a high level of accommodation with a somewhat slower pace—but still very high pace—of asset purchases and our interest rate policy, we do have other things we can do if we need to ramp up again.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, we’re hopeful that the economy will continue to make progress, and that we’ll begin to see the whites of the eyes of the end of the recovery and the beginning of the more normal period of economic growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, again, we’re not doing less.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ll see how accommodation shapes up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But while we are slowing asset purchases a bit, again, we expect the total balance sheet to be quite large and maintained for—at a large level for a long time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we expect to keep rates low for a very long time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re providing a great deal of accommodation to the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I agree with your observation, and the observation of the paper that you cited, that there is a case for being particularly aggressive, and I think we have been aggressive to try to keep the economy growing, and we are seeing progress in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I would dispute the idea that we’re not providing a lot of accommodation to the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we’ve been in a—it’s been about a little over four years now since the recovery began, four and a half years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s been a slow recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a number of reasons for that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s—of course, that’s something for econometricians and historians to grapple with, but there have been a number of factors which have contributed to slower growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They include, for example, the observation that financial crises tend to disrupt the economy, may affect innovation, new products, new firms.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We had a big housing bust, and so, the construction sector, of course, has been quite depressed for a while.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve had continuing financial disturbances in Europe and elsewhere.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve had very tight, on the whole—except for in 2009—we had very tight fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: People don’t appreciate how tight fiscal policy has been.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At this stage in the last recession, which was a much milder recession, state, local, and federal governments had hired 400,000 additional workers from the trough of the recession.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At the same point in this recovery, the change in state, local, and federal government workers is minus 600,000.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there’s about a million workers difference in how many people are—have been employed at all levels of government.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, fiscal policy has been tight, contractionary, so there have been a lot of headwinds.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: All that being said, we have been disappointed in the pace of growth, and we don’t fully understand why.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Some of it may just be a slower pace of underlying potential, at least temporarily.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Productivity has been disappointing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It may be that there’s been some bad luck—for example, the effects of the European crisis and the like.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But compared to other advanced industrial countries—Europe, the U.K., Japan—compared to other countries and advanced industrial countries recovering from financial crises, the U.S. recovery has actually been better than most.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s not been good, it’s not been satisfactory.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Obviously, we still have a labor market where it’s not easy for people to find work.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: A lot of young people can’t get the experience and entrée into the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, I think, given all of the things that we faced, it’s perhaps, at least in retrospect, not shocking that the recovery has been somewhat tepid.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, as always, of course, I don’t address specific fiscal actions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I will say a couple of things about this deal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One is that, relative to where we were in September and October, it certainly is nice that there’s been a bipartisan deal, and that it looks like it’s going to pass both houses of Congress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s also, at least directionally, what I have recommended in testimony, which is that it eases a bit the fiscal restraint in the next couple of years, a period where the economy needs help to finish the recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, in place of that, it achieves savings further out in the 10-year window.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So those things are positive things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Of course, there’s a lot more work to be done, I have no doubt about that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But it’s certainly a better situation than we had in September and October, or in January during the fiscal cliff, for that matter.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think it will be good for confidence if fiscal policy and congressional leaders work together to—even if there’s—even if the outcomes are small, as this one was, it’s a good thing that they are working cooperatively and making some progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Yes, the system is certainly safer, and one indication of that is the amount of capital that large banks hold.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, for example, on the capital side, we have imposed Basel III requirements, much tougher requirements, as you know, for the large banks, with surcharges that will be part of that process.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve imposed—I think one of the main innovations, which I am very pleased with, is the use of stress testing, trying to see whether banks have enough capital not only to deal with normal fluctuations, but to deal with the very severe combination of a sharp downturn in the economy and very bad financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think that has been a very important test, both of banks’ abilities to survive a bad situation but also their abilities to measure their risks, which was something that was very deficient going into the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Beyond that, we’re looking at a leverage ratio, of course, that we expect to complete fairly soon, the possibility of having debt required at the holding company to assist in a resolution, we’re looking at capital for—to backstop firms that rely heavily on short-term wholesale funding.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there’s a much stronger capital-oriented drive at this point to strengthen our financial system—and that’s just one dimension.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And then there’s liquidity and many other aspects.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think, you know, it’s not really up to me to say whether these things are tough enough or not.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, you and other observers who are writing about this and thinking about this obviously will have your opinions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, I guess, what I would say about that is that we’re not done.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have still some important rules to complete, although all of them are well advanced.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And as we get these rules done and implement them, I’m sure they’ll make a very substantial difference in the safety of the system, but whether more needs to be done—I’ll leave that as an open question, and I think we’ll be working on this for some time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, on the centennial review, let me just say, first, that one of the things that I’m proud of, and I’ve tried to accomplish over the past eight years, is to increase the transparency of the Fed and to increase the accountability of the Fed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You mentioned those trips to Capitol Hill.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’ve testified many times, as have a number of my colleagues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There is this notion that the Fed is not audited or it has all kinds of secret books—all these things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you well know, we have complete openness to the General Accountability Office, the GAO—Government Accountability Office.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have an IG, Inspector General, of our own.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have a private accounting firm that does all the books as well under very tough standards.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We publish regular reports on all aspects of our operations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’re very open, and we are by all means willing to work with Congress to see if there’s anything that they think might be done better or in a more effective way.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we’re open to doing that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I hope that those reviewing the central bank will, of course, recognize that central banking is an old activity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The 17th century is when the Swedish Riksbank and the Bank of England began operation, so we know a lot about central banking.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a lot of experts on central banking, a lot of experts on monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Every major country has a central bank.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’re not starting from scratch.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, there are a lot of people with a lot of expertise on this, and I hope that, as we talk about these issues, that we are bringing in serious people who understand these issues and who can make good suggestions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, there are a range of different mandates around the world.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are some single mandates, there are some dual mandates, et cetera.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s our sense that the dual mandate has served us well here—in particular, that the Fed has been able, at times, to speed the recovery from recession and help put people back to work more quickly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Of course, we can’t do anything about long-run employment opportunities, but we can help the economy recover more quickly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think that that’s valuable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would note, by the way, that at the current moment, it doesn’t really matter whether we have one mandate or two, because we’re below our inflation target and we—unemployment is above where we’d like it to be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So both sides of our mandate are pointing exactly in the same direction, which is to provide strong accommodation to the economy to help it recover.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Looking in retrospect, I—you know, that’s a very hard question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Every decision you make, of course, is done in real time, with deficient information and whatever you know at the time and whatever the experts are telling you about any particular issue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Obviously, we were slow to recognize the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I was slow to recognize the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In retrospect, it was a traditional classic crisis, but in a very, very different guise: different types of financial instruments, different types of institutions, which made it, for a historian like me, more difficult to see.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Whether or not we could have prevented or done more about it, that’s another question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You know, by the time I became Chairman, it was already 2006, and house prices were already declining.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most of the mortgages had been made, but, obviously, it would have been good to have recognized that earlier and try to take more preventive action.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, we’ve done everything we can think of, essentially, to strengthen the Fed’s ability to monitor the financial markets, to take actions to stabilize the economy and the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I think, going forward, we’re much better prepared for—to deal with these kinds of events than we were when I became Chairman in 2006.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Ah.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, most of my family now is in North Carolina, and I’ve got a number of family members in Charlotte and also in Durham.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So my wife and I are going to spend the Christmas vacation in North Carolina.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I still have—my uncle still lives in Dillon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: He’s 85, and very, very, very chipper.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I will answer your question, and I’ll try and help maybe do a better job on Binya’s question as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do think, again, of the asset purchases as a secondary tool behind interest rate policy, and we do think that the cost–benefit ratio, particularly as the assets on the balance sheet get large, that it moves in a way that’s less favorable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The costs involved include, you know, managing the exit from that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The possible—it’s very unlikely that the Fed will have losses in any comprehensive sense.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve already put $350 billion of profits back to the Treasury since 2009, which is about as much as we delivered to the Treasury between 1990 and 2007 combined.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, over any period of time, clearly, the Fed is actually making a good bit of money for the taxpayer and for the government.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But it could be that if interest rates rise quickly, for example, that we would be in a situation of not giving remittances to the Treasury for a couple of years, and that would create problems, no doubt, for the Fed in terms of congressional response.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are issues of how well we understand and can manage the effects of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think, for example, that an important difference between asset purchases and interest rate policy is that asset purchases work by affecting what is called the “term premium,” which is essentially the additional part of the interest rate which investors require as compensation for holding longer-term securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We just don’t understand very well—and when I say “we,” I mean the economics profession—don’t understand very well what moves the term premium.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, we saw last summer—we saw a very big jump in the term premium that was very destabilizing and created a lot of stress in financial markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there are a number of reasons why asset purchases, while effective, while I think they have been important, are less attractive tools than traditional interest rate policy, and that’s the reason why we have relied primarily on interest rates, but used asset purchases as a supplement when we’ve needed it to keep forward progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think that, you know, obviously there are some financial stability issues involved there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We look at the possibility that asset purchases have led to bubbly pricing in certain markets or in excessive leverage or excessive risk-taking.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We don’t think that that’s happened to an extent which is a danger to the system, except other than that when those positions unwind, like we saw over the summer, they can create some bumpiness in interest rate markets, in particular.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our general philosophy on financial stability issues is, where we can, that we try to address it first and foremost by making sure that the banking system and the financial system are as strong as possible—if banks have a lot of capital, they can withstand losses, for example—and by using whatever other tools we have to try to avoid bubbles or other kinds of financial risks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, I don’t think that you can completely ignore financial stability concerns in monetary policy because we can’t control them perfectly, and there may be situations when financial instability has implications for our mandate, which is jobs and inflation, which we saw, of course, in the Great Recession.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it’s a very complex issue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it will be many years before central banks have completely worked out exactly how best to deal with financial instability questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Certainly, the first line of defense for us is regulatory and other types of measures, but we do have to pay some attention to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would say at this point, though, that the asset purchases program—the last one—is well on its way to meeting our economic objective, and I am very pleased that we’re able to, over time, wind down this program, slowing the pace of purchases on current plans, because we reached our objective rather than because the costs or efficacy issues became important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think that, in this case, that that’s not a concern at this juncture with respect to this program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, it’s very hard to know—in terms of the study, it’s very hard to know.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s an imprecise science to try to measure these effects.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think that study—I think it was a very interesting study, but it was on the upper end of the estimates that people have gotten in a variety of studies looking at the effects of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, I’m pretty comfortable with the idea that this program did, in fact, create jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I cited some figures.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To repeat one of them, the Blue Chip forecasts for unemployment in this current quarter—made before we began our program—were on the order 7.8 percent, and that was before the fiscal cliff deal, which even—created even more fiscal headwinds for the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, of course, we’re now at 7 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’m not saying that the asset purchases made all that difference, but it made some of the difference, and I think it has helped create jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And you can see how it works.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, the asset purchases brought down long-term interest rates, brought down mortgage rates, brought down corporate bond yields, brought down car loan interest rates, and we’ve seen the response in those areas as the economy has done better.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Moreover, again, this has been done in the face of very tight, unusually tight fiscal policy for a recovery period.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I do think it’s been effective, but the precise size of the impact is something I think that we can very reasonably disagree about, and that work will continue on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As I said before, the uncertainty about the impact and the uncertainty about the effects of ending programs and so on is one of the reasons why we have treated this as a supplementary tool rather than as our primary tool.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, obviously it has a big economic effect on those directly affected, you know, who are receiving benefits, and we do have an unusually large number of long-term unemployed people in the United States now, which is obviously a major concern and one that I cited in my opening remarks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The effects of ending extended unemployment benefits, quantitatively, for the economy overall, are probably not very large because they work in two directions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the one hand, by putting the benefits into the system, you are providing additional income.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That income is spent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: People receiving unemployment benefits obviously tend to spend a very high fraction of their income.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That is a positive for growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the other side, it—probably some folks who are—can no longer qualify for unemployment benefits will just drop out of the labor force, and that will bring the unemployment rate down, but, for some sense, the wrong reason.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, overall, it will have—it could have a very small effect on the measured unemployment rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, I think that issue needs to be discussed more in terms of the impact on those most directly affected rather than on the overall economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Excellent question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think the first thing to agree to is that Congress is our boss.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Reserve is an independent agency within the government.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s important that we maintain our policy independence in order to be able to make decisions without short-term political interference.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At the same time, it’s up to the Congress to set our structure, to set our mandate, and that’s entirely legitimate, and we need to go and explain ourselves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We need to explain why certain approaches are not so good or might be better.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, obviously, they represent the public, and they certainly have every right to set the terms on which the Federal Reserve operates and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, I think that we are, in fact, an effective central bank, that we are near the frontier in terms of transparency, in terms of the effectiveness of our policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re highly respected among central bankers and other policymakers around the world.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, I hope that when they do review the Fed, if that’s what they do, again, that they rely on expertise and highly qualified individuals who know the ins and outs of central banking and monetary policy, which are not simple matters.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And it would be very interesting to have a thorough discussion of many of the issues involved that the Fed has been engaged in.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, I hope it will be on a high level that uses the best and most qualified people debating, you know, what changes, if any, are needed and—or, you know, what’s being done right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think a lot of the declines in the participation rate are, in fact, demographic or structural, reflecting sociological trends.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Many of the changes that we’re seeing now, we were also seeing to some degree even before the crisis, and we have a number of staffers here at the Fed who have studied participation rates and the like.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think a lot of the unemployment decline that we’ve seen, contrary to sometimes what you hear, I think a lot of it really does come from jobs as opposed to declining participation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, there certainly is a portion of the decline in participation, which is related to people dropping out of the labor force because they are discouraged, because their skills have become obsolete, because they’ve lost attachment to the labor force, and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Fed can address that, to some extent, if—you know, if we’re able to get the economy closer to full employment, then some people who are discouraged or who have been unemployed for a long time might find that they have opportunities to rejoin the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I think, fundamentally, that training our workforce to fit the needs of 21st-century industry in the world that we have today is the job of both the private educational sector and the government educational sector.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have many strengths in our educational sector, including outstanding universities, but we have a lot of weaknesses, as you know.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are many, many factors that affect participation—employment, wages, and so on, but the one I think that we can most directly affect is the skill level of our workforce.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that doesn’t mean everybody has to go to get a Ph.D. People have different needs, different interests.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But that, I think, is one of the biggest challenges that our society faces, and if we don’t address it, then we’re going to see a larger and larger number of people who are either unemployed, underemployed, or working at very low wages, which obviously is not something we want to see.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you.
